title: Roman Abramovich set to personally bankroll £500m Chelsea project: This is Blues' plan
text: Roman Abramovich set to personally bankroll £500m Chelsea project: This is Blues' plan CHELSEA owner Roman Abramovich is reportedly set to personally fund Stamford Bridge's redevelopment. PUBLISHED: 03:40, Wed, Jan 11, 2017 | UPDATED: 03:47, Wed, Jan 11, 2017 The project will cost around £500million, and approval for their planning application is expected to be granted tonight. Hammersmith and Fulham Council will be presented with proposal to expand Chelsea's home into a 60,000-seater stadium. The council have recommended to give the Blues the go ahead, with the planning and development control committee meeting at 7pm today. GETTY Roman Abramovich is set to personally fund Chelsea's stadium redevelopment And according to The Telegraph , Russian owner Abramovich will pump his own money into the massive expansion. The 50-year-old has been at the club since 2003 and Chelsea have since become a powerhouse in English football, winning the Premier League four times and the Champions League once. In 2016, Abramovich's net worth was reportedly said to be worth around £5.7billion, and he has invested plenty into Chelsea during his 13-and-a-half years in west London. GETTY Construction at Stamford Bridge will begin in 2018, with Chelsea moving out for at least three years [Abramovich] wants to ensure the stadium upgrade doesn't effect [Chelsea] on the pitch A regular attender to matches, the billionaire businessman wants to ensure the stadium upgrade doesn't effect his club on the pitch. Arsene Wenger has often put Arsenal's move to the Emirates down to their tight transfer budget over the post decade, hindering their success. Under Antonio Conte now, Chelsea have a potential long-term set-up to keep the club at the highest level, with a Premier League title on the cards this season. GETTY Chelsea are likely to use Wembley as a temporary home after Tottenham vacate it How much does it cost to live near your club's stadium? Tue, November 29, 2016 Express Sport reveals which football stadium in the United Kingdom costs the most to live near, based on research by online estate agent Hatched Getty Images 1 of 22 Express Sport takes a look at which football stadiums would cost the most to live near, based on the average house prices of properties sharing the same postcode Come 2018, the Blues will have to leave Stamford Bridge for at least three seasons while construction takes place, with Wembley being lined up as a temporary home after Chelsea's London rivals Tottenham move back out . Twickenham has also apparently been considered as an alternative should the prospect of using Wembley fall through. One of Chelsea's biggest problems though with their redevelopment is how the underground and overground railway lines are so close to the ground, leaving little extra land space. The plan is ultimately to excavate down to create more room for the expansion. Related articles
